caveats:
(1) Weekly deaths data are based on Date of Death and differ from other deaths statistics based on date of registration. These data are provisional and subject to revision during the full process of producing death statistics.

(2) Totals are by Date of Death. Week ending Sunday.

(3) Weekly totals will differ from those in the death registrations time series as deaths are registered at the time of burial or cremation of the body.

(4) An average of 5% of Deaths are registered 2 weeks or more after Date of Death therefore weekly totals are expected to increase over time as Death Registrations are submitted and processed.

(5) Overseas addresses or where location could not be determined and records where the persons sex is missing or not in Male or Female have been excluded as these numbers are too low to publish a weekly total.

(6) The accuracy of any administrative data, which includes but is not limited to address information is subject to human error.

(7) The data provided has been collated to the best of our ability and may have a small variance to any alternative publications.

groups.name: undefined_name
groups.title: Percentage of respondents who reported it was hard or very hard to stay connected with family, whnau and friends outside their household, over the past 7 days
groups.caveats:
This survey uses an opt-in sampling method based on people who have taken part in the New Zealand Crime and Victims Survey (NZCVS) and agreed to be contacted about future research. As a result, there could be bias associated with the respondents of the survey. The findings reported should not be applied to the overall NZ population.

Approximately 370 people are contacted each week resulting in approximately 300 finalised interviews.

1) Wave 1 data collected over 14-28th April 2020. This mainly covers COVID-19 Alert Level 4 (except 28th April 2020 which was COVID-19 Alert Level 3). Wave 2 data collected between 30 September and 22 October 2020.

2) This survey uses an opt-in quota sampling method, which is a type of non-probability sampling. As a result, there is some bias associated with the respondents of the survey. The findings reported cannot be applied to the overall NZ population.

groups.title: Respondents who said in general their health was good, very good, or excellent - provisional
groups.caveats:
1) Insufficient data was collected for week ending August 9, 2020.

2) This survey samples people who have previously taken part in the New Zealand Health Survey and agreed to be contacted about future research. As a result, there could be bias associated with the respondents and thus the findings of this survey.

3) Data are for the week ended Sunday.

4) Approximately 300 people (aged 15+ years) are interviewed each day.

5) There are some limitations to the sample used, such as small numbers of Asian and Pacific respondents.

groups.name: undefined_name
groups.title: Respondents who said they slept for the recommended time - provisional
groups.caveats:
1) Insufficient data was collected for week ending August 9, 2020.

2) Percentage of respondents who, over the past 7 days, said they have on average slept for the recommended number of hours in a 24-hour period, including all naps and sleeps. The Ministry of Healths sleep recommendations are adapted from the National Sleep Foundation. Recommended hours of sleep vary from 7-10 hours depending on age.

3) This survey samples people who have previously taken part in the New Zealand Health Survey and agreed to be contacted about future research. As a result, there could be bias associated with the respondents and thus the findings of this survey.

4) Data are for the week ended Sunday.

5) Approximately 300 people (aged 15+ years) are interviewed each day.

6) There are some limitations to the sample used, such as small numbers of Asian and Pacific respondents.

groups.name: undefined_name
groups.title: Respondents experiencing depressive and/or anxiety-related symptoms in the past 7 days - provisional
groups.caveats:
1) Insufficient data was collected for week ending August 9, 2020.

2) Measured using an adapted version of the Patient Health Questionnaire-2 (PHQ-2) and Generalised Anxiety Disorder-2 (GAD-2). These cover questions about frequency of depressed mood (for example, little interest or pleasure in doing things) and about experience of anxiety symptoms (for example, feeling nervous, anxious or on edge).

3) This survey samples people who have previously taken part in the New Zealand Health Survey and agreed to be contacted about future research. As a result, there could be bias associated with the respondents and thus the findings of this survey.

4) Data are for the week ended Sunday.

5) Approximately 300 people (aged 15+ years) are interviewed each day.

6) There are some limitations to the sample used, such as small numbers of Asian and Pacific respondents.

source: Stats NZ, System of Environmental  Economic Accounting
caveats:
1. CO-e is carbon dioxide equivalent.
  2. This experimental production-based emissions data is done within the System of Environmental Economic Accounting (SEEA) framework
  3. Production of greenhouse gases by Australian and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification 2006 (ANZSIC06), and households are on a residence basis. The national accounts' residence principle means that emissions by resident economic units are included even if these occur outside the territory (for example, resident airlines and shipping companies operating in the rest of the world).
  4. Industry and household emissions are based on the range of direct emissions produced by an industry or household which can span Greenhouse Gas Inventory sectors.
  5. Emissions are expressed in carbon dioxide equivalents, which are the emissions of greenhouse gases weighted by their 100-year global warming potential (GWP). The GWPs are based on those from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, Fourth Assessment Report, 2007.
  6. Seasonally adjusted emissions values are not additive.
measure: This is a measure of the GHG emissions produced by various industry groups in NZ, shown in Kilotonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent

source: Treasury, Stats NZ, Reserve Bank & various
caveats:
1) The Regional Activity Index (RAI) represents year-on-year activity growth for that region. A positive reading means that many of the underlying input indicators are growing at above-average rates, and vice versa for a negative reading. For interpretation guidance see RAI documentation.

2) All RAI components are presented in terms of annual percentage changes, standardised to have mean = 0 and standard deviation = 1. For technical details see RAI documentation.

3) As the benefit system has changed over time, the MSD jobseekers data contains modelled estimates of the number of claimants that would have been eligible under the current benefit system pre-2013.

4) We reverse the sign of the RAI component for Jobseeker growth, so that these deviations move in the same direction as other economic variables (i.e. dips in a contraction).

5) Consumer card spend is based on Paymark card expenditure.

6) Electricity grid demand is sourced from the Electricity Authority's reconciled demand series. It has been allocated to each region using a concordance developed by Stats NZ.

groups.name: Enterprises
groups.title: Monthly enterprise counts
groups.caveats: Enterprises: A business or service entity operating in New Zealand. It can be a company, partnership, trust, estate, incorporated society, producer board, local or central government organisation, voluntary organisation or self-employed individual.

groups.name: Enterprise entries
groups.title: Monthly enterprise counts - entries
groups.caveats: Enterprise entry: Enterprises which are in the current reference period but not in the previous reference period. This includes new enterprise registrations, reactivations of cancelled enterprises, and enterprises that have recommenced remitting GST. Also include enterprises becoming significant in the current reference period.

groups.name: Enterprise exits
groups.title: Monthly enterprise counts - exits
groups.caveats: Enterprise exit: Enterprises which are not in the current reference period but in the previous reference period. This includes enterprise that have ceased and cancelled their GST registration, enterprise that have ceased remitting GST for an extended period of time, and enterprise that have been involved in mergers and acquisitions where the GST number has changed. Also include enterprises becoming insignificant in the current reference period.

caveats:
*Data refers to respondents who said they had drunk alcohol in the last 4 weeks. Wave 1 respondents were asked about drinking changes since being in lockdown, while wave 2 respondents were asked to compare drinking levels since before lockdown with the last 2 weeks.

Data collected for wave 1 between 7-13 April 2020 (which corresponded with Alert Level 4 lockdown days 13 19). Data collected for wave 2 between 10-19 June 2020 (which corresponded with Alert Level 1 days 2 11). Wave 2 includes people who completed the Wave 1 survey as well as new respondents.

Results from the wave 2 study can be found here: Post lockdown survey - the impact on health risk behaviours.

This survey uses an opt-in online panel sample, which is a type of non-probability sampling. As a result, there is some bias associated with the respondents of the survey. The findings reported cannot be applied to the overall NZ population.
